urls.title: Wild swimming and sewage ‚Äì beware, red flags don't always mean rough seas - Practical Boat Owner
urls.description: The red flags were flying when I went for a swim at Boscombe Pier. I thought nothing of it. Yes, the sea was a tiny bit choppy, but I had my tow-float, and I was only planning a quick dip in shallow water, swimming parallel with the shore. So I gave the RNLI hut a wide berth. The lifeguard came running after me. ‚ÄòWait!‚Äô I groaned. He was going to tell me off, and now it would be awkward if I still wanted to swim. But what he said surprised me. ‚ÄòI wouldn‚Äôt advise going in today. The water quality‚Äôs not very good. There‚Äôs been a¬† sewage overspill after the storms.‚Äô Sewage? No, please! Not on my beautiful beach. But apparently after heavy rains the run-off is common. All this time, I‚Äôd assumed the red flags were just there to warn of rough seas. In fact, Boscombe ‚Äì one of the beaches the UK flocked to during the Covid pandemic ‚Äì was identified in a recent Guardian report as being one of those where untreated wastewater is discharged. Article continues below‚Ä¶ Boscombe is not alone. Accordi
